[![Arkansasrivermap.jpg](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/27/Arkansasrivermap.jpg/256px-
Arkansasrivermap.jpg)](/wiki/File:Arkansasrivermap.jpg) The Arkansas River
flows through Colorado, Kansas, Oklahoma, and Arkansas, and its watershed also
drains parts of Texas, New Mexico and Missouri.  
  
The **Arkansas River** is a major [tributary](/wiki/Tributary "Tributary") of
the [Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River"). It
generally flows to the east and southeast as it traverses the U.S. states of
[Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado"), [Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas"),
[Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma"), and [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas
"Arkansas"). The river's source basin lies in the [western United
States](/wiki/Western_United_States "Western United States") in Colorado,
specifically the [Arkansas River Valley](/wiki/Arkansas_River_Valley "Arkansas
River Valley"), where the headwaters derive from the [snowpack](/wiki/Snowpack
"Snowpack") in the [Sawatch](/wiki/Sawatch_Range "Sawatch Range") and
[Mosquito](/wiki/Mosquito_Range "Mosquito Range") mountain ranges. It then
flows east into the [Midwest](/wiki/Midwestern_United_States "Midwestern
United States") via Kansas, and finally into the
[South](/wiki/Southern_United_States "Southern United States") through
Oklahoma and Arkansas.

At 1,469 miles (2,364 km), it is the sixth-longest river in the [United
States](/wiki/United_States "United States"),[5] the second-longest tributary
in the Mississippi–[Missouri](/wiki/Missouri_River "Missouri River") system,
and the [45th longest river in the world](/wiki/List_of_rivers_by_length "List
of rivers by length"). Its origin is in the [Rocky
Mountains](/wiki/Rocky_Mountains "Rocky Mountains") in [Lake County,
Colorado](/wiki/Lake_County,_Colorado "Lake County, Colorado"), near
[Leadville](/wiki/Leadville,_Colorado "Leadville, Colorado"). In 1859,
[placer](/wiki/Placer_mining "Placer mining") gold discovered in the Leadville
area brought thousands seeking to strike it rich, but the easily recovered
placer gold was quickly exhausted.[6] The Arkansas River's mouth is at
[Napoleon, Arkansas](/wiki/Napoleon,_Arkansas "Napoleon, Arkansas"), and its
drainage basin covers nearly 170,000 sq mi (440,300 km²).[3] In terms of
volume, the river is much smaller than the Missouri and
[Ohio](/wiki/Ohio_River "Ohio River") Rivers, with a mean discharge of roughly
41,000 cubic feet per second (1,200 m3/s).

The Arkansas from its headwaters to the [100th meridian
west](/wiki/100th_meridian_west "100th meridian west") formed part of the
[U.S.-Mexico border](/wiki/U.S.-Mexico_border "U.S.-Mexico border") from the
[Adams–Onís Treaty](/wiki/Adams%E2%80%93On%C3%ADs_Treaty "Adams–Onís Treaty")
(in force 1821) until the [Texas Annexation](/wiki/Texas_Annexation "Texas
Annexation") or [Treaty of Guadalupe
Hidalgo](/wiki/Treaty_of_Guadalupe_Hidalgo "Treaty of Guadalupe Hidalgo").

##
Pronunciations[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Arkansas_River&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Pronunciations")]

Name pronunciation varies by region. Many people in western states, including
[Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas") and [Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado"),
pronounce it [/ɑːrˈkænzəs/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English")
[_ar-**KAN** -zəs_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key
"Help:Pronunciation respelling key"),[7] People in [Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma
"Oklahoma") and [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas") typically pronounce it
[/ˈɑːrkənsɔː/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English") [_**AR** -kən-
saw_](/wiki/Help:Pronunciation_respelling_key "Help:Pronunciation respelling
key"), which is how the state is always pronounced according to a state law
passed in 1881.[8]

## Hydrography[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Arkansas_River&action=edit&section=2
"Edit section: Hydrography")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Arkansas_head_waters.jpg/220px-
Arkansas_head_waters.jpg)](/wiki/File:Arkansas_head_waters.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Arkansas_head_waters.jpg "Enlarge")

The headwaters of the Arkansas near [Leadville,
Colorado](/wiki/Leadville,_Colorado "Leadville, Colorado")

The Arkansas has three distinct sections in its long path through central
North America. At its headwaters, the Arkansas runs as a steep fast-flowing
mountain river through the Rockies in its narrow valley, dropping 4,600 feet
(1.4 km) in 120 miles (193 km). This section supports extensive [whitewater
rafting](/wiki/Whitewater_rafting "Whitewater rafting"), including The Numbers
(near [Granite, Colorado](/wiki/Granite,_Colorado "Granite, Colorado")),
[Brown's Canyon](/wiki/Browns_Canyon_National_Monument "Browns Canyon National
Monument"), and the [Royal Gorge](/wiki/Royal_Gorge "Royal Gorge").

At [Cañon City, Colorado](/wiki/Ca%C3%B1on_City,_Colorado "Cañon City,
Colorado"), the Arkansas River valley widens and flattens markedly. Just west
of [Pueblo, Colorado](/wiki/Pueblo,_Colorado "Pueblo, Colorado"), the river
enters the [Great Plains](/wiki/Great_Plains "Great Plains"). Through the rest
of [Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado"), [Kansas](/wiki/Kansas "Kansas"), and
much of [Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma"), it is a typical Great Plains
riverway, with wide, shallow banks subject to seasonal flooding and periods of
dwindling flow. Tributaries include the [Cimarron
River](/wiki/Cimarron_River_\(Arkansas_River\) "Cimarron River \(Arkansas
River\)") and the [Salt Fork Arkansas River](/wiki/Salt_Fork_Arkansas_River
"Salt Fork Arkansas River").

In eastern Oklahoma the river begins to widen further into a more contained
consistent channel. To maintain more reliable flow rates, a series of large
reservoir lakes have been built on the Arkansas and its intersecting
tributaries including the [Canadian](/wiki/Canadian_River "Canadian River"),
[Verdigris](/wiki/Verdigris_River "Verdigris River"), [Neosho
(Grand)](/wiki/Grand_River_\(Oklahoma\) "Grand River \(Oklahoma\)"),
[Illinois](/wiki/Illinois_River_\(Arkansas\) "Illinois River \(Arkansas\)"),
and [Poteau](/wiki/Poteau_River "Poteau River") rivers.[9] These locks and
dams allow the river to be navigable by barges and large river craft downriver
of [Muskogee, Oklahoma](/wiki/Muskogee,_Oklahoma "Muskogee, Oklahoma"), where
the [McClellan-Kerr Arkansas River Navigation System](/wiki/McClellan-
Kerr_Arkansas_River_Navigation_System "McClellan-Kerr Arkansas River
Navigation System") joins in with the Verdigris River.

Into western [Arkansas](/wiki/Arkansas "Arkansas"), the river path works
between the encroaching [Boston](/wiki/Boston_Mountains "Boston Mountains")
and [Ouachita](/wiki/Ouachita_Mountains "Ouachita Mountains") Mountains,
including many isolated, flat-topped mesas, buttes, or
[monadnocks](/wiki/Monadnock "Monadnock") such as [Mount
Nebo](/wiki/Mount_Nebo_\(Arkansas\) "Mount Nebo \(Arkansas\)"), [Petit Jean
Mountain](/wiki/Petit_Jean_State_Park "Petit Jean State Park"), and [Mount
Magazine](/wiki/Mount_Magazine "Mount Magazine"), the highest point in the
state. The river valley then expands as it encounters much flatter land
beginning just west of [Little Rock, Arkansas](/wiki/Little_Rock,_Arkansas
"Little Rock, Arkansas"). It continues eastward across the plains and forests
of eastern Arkansas until it flows into the [Mississippi
River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River").

Water flow in the Arkansas River (as measured in central [Kansas](/wiki/Kansas
"Kansas")) has dropped from approximately 248 cubic feet per second (7 m³/s)
average from 1944-1963 to 53 cubic feet per second (1.5 m³/s) average from
1984–2003, largely because of the pumping of [groundwater](/wiki/Groundwater
"Groundwater") for [irrigation](/wiki/Irrigation "Irrigation") in eastern
[Colorado](/wiki/Colorado "Colorado") and western [Kansas](/wiki/Kansas
"Kansas").

Important cities along the Arkansas River include [Pueblo,
Colorado](/wiki/Pueblo,_Colorado "Pueblo, Colorado"), [Garden City,
Kansas](/wiki/Garden_City,_Kansas "Garden City, Kansas"), [Dodge City,
Kansas](/wiki/Dodge_City,_Kansas "Dodge City, Kansas"), [Wichita,
Kansas](/wiki/Wichita,_Kansas "Wichita, Kansas"), [Tulsa,
Oklahoma](/wiki/Tulsa,_Oklahoma "Tulsa, Oklahoma"), [Fort Smith,
Arkansas](/wiki/Fort_Smith,_Arkansas "Fort Smith, Arkansas"), and [Little
Rock, Arkansas](/wiki/Little_Rock,_Arkansas "Little Rock, Arkansas").

The [I-40 bridge disaster](/wiki/I-40_bridge_disaster "I-40 bridge disaster")
of May 2002 took place on [I-40](/wiki/Interstate_40 "Interstate 40")'s
crossing of [Kerr Reservoir](/wiki/Robert_S._Kerr_Reservoir "Robert S. Kerr
Reservoir") on the Arkansas River near [Webbers Falls,
Oklahoma](/wiki/Webbers_Falls,_Oklahoma "Webbers Falls, Oklahoma").

## Allocation
problems[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Arkansas_River&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Allocation problems")]

Since 1902, Kansas has claimed Colorado takes too much of the river's water,
resulting in a number of lawsuits before the [U.S. Supreme
Court](/wiki/U.S._Supreme_Court "U.S. Supreme Court") that continue to this
day,[10] generally under the name of _[Kansas v.
Colorado](/wiki/Kansas_v._Colorado "Kansas v. Colorado")_. The problems over
the possession and use of Arkansas River water by Colorado and Kansas led to
the creation of an [interstate compact](/wiki/Interstate_compact "Interstate
compact") or agreement between the two states.[10] While Congress approved the
Arkansas River Compact in 1949,[10] the compact did not stop further disputes
by the two states over water rights to the river.

The Kansas-Oklahoma Arkansas River Basin Compact was created in 1965 to
promote mutual consideration and equity over water use in the basin shared by
those states. It led to the Kansas-Oklahoma Arkansas River Commission, which
was charged with administering the compact and reducing pollution. The compact
was approved and implemented by both states in 1970, and has been in force
since then.[9]

## Riverway
commerce[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Arkansas_River&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Riverway commerce")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/f6/Kerr-
McClellan_map.png/170px-Kerr-McClellan_map.png)](/wiki/File:Kerr-
McClellan_map.png)

[](/wiki/File:Kerr-McClellan_map.png "Enlarge")

Inland waterway system with McClellan-Kerr Navigational Channel shown in red

The [McClellan-Kerr Arkansas River Navigation System](/wiki/McClellan-
Kerr_Arkansas_River_Navigation_System "McClellan-Kerr Arkansas River
Navigation System") begins at the [Tulsa Port of
Catoosa](/wiki/Tulsa_Port_of_Catoosa "Tulsa Port of Catoosa") on the
[Verdigris River](/wiki/Verdigris_River "Verdigris River"), enters the
Arkansas River near Muskogee, and runs via an extensive lock and dam system to
the Mississippi River. Through Oklahoma and Arkansas, dams which artificially
deepen and widen the river to sustain commercial barge traffic and
recreational use give the river the appearance of a series of
reservoirs.[_[citation needed](/wiki/Wikipedia:Citation_needed
"Wikipedia:Citation needed")_]

The McClellan-Kerr Arkansas River Navigation System diverts from the Arkansas
River 2.5 mi (4.0 km) upstream of the [Wilbur D. Mills
Dam](/wiki/Wilbur_D._Mills_Dam "Wilbur D. Mills Dam") to avoid the long
winding route which the lower Arkansas River follows. This circuitous portion
of the Arkansas River between the Wilbur D. Mills Dam and the Mississippi
River was historically bypassed by river vessels; early steamboats instead
following a network of rivers—known as the Arkansas Post Canal—which flowed
north of the lower Arkansas River and followed a shorter and more direct route
to the Mississippi River. When the McClellan–Kerr Arkansas River Navigation
System was constructed between 1963 and 1970, the Arkansas Post Canal was
significantly improved, while the lower Arkansas River continued to be
bypassed by commercial vessels.[11]

## The river in
history[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Arkansas_River&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: The river in history")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/30/Devil%27s_Punch_Bowl_falls%2C_from_Robert_N._Dennis_collection_of_stereoscopic_views.jpg/220px-
Devil%27s_Punch_Bowl_falls%2C_from_Robert_N._Dennis_collection_of_stereoscopic_views.jpg)](/wiki/File:Devil%27s_Punch_Bowl_falls,_from_Robert_N._Dennis_collection_of_stereoscopic_views.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Devil%27s_Punch_Bowl_falls,_from_Robert_N._Dennis_collection_of_stereoscopic_views.jpg
"Enlarge")

Devil's Punch Bowl falls, Grand Canyon of the Arkansas River in Colorado, from
Robert N. Dennis collection of stereoscopic views

Many nations of [Native Americans](/wiki/Native_Americans_in_the_United_States
"Native Americans in the United States") lived near, or along, the 1,450-mile
(2334-km) stretch of the Arkansas River for thousands of years. The first
Europeans to see the river were members of the [Spanish](/wiki/Spanish_people
"Spanish people") [Coronado](/wiki/Francisco_V%C3%A1squez_de_Coronado
"Francisco Vásquez de Coronado") expedition on June 29, 1541. Also in the
1540s, [Hernando de Soto](/wiki/Hernando_de_Soto_\(explorer\) "Hernando de
Soto \(explorer\)") discovered the junction of the Arkansas with the
Mississippi. The Spanish originally called the river _Napeste_.[9] "The name
"Arkansas" was first applied by Father [Jacques
Marquette](/wiki/Jacques_Marquette "Jacques Marquette"), who called the river
_Akansa_ in his journal of 1673. The Joliet-Marquette expedition travelled the
[Mississippi River](/wiki/Mississippi_River "Mississippi River") from [Prairie
du Chien, Wisconsin](/wiki/Prairie_du_Chien,_Wisconsin "Prairie du Chien,
Wisconsin") towards the Gulf of Mexico, but turned back at the mouth of the
Arkansas River. By that time, they had encountered Native Americans carrying
European trinkets, and feared confrontation with Spanish conquistadors.

[Jean-Baptiste Bénard de la Harpe](/wiki/Jean-Baptiste_B%C3%A9nard_de_la_Harpe
"Jean-Baptiste Bénard de la Harpe"), a French trader, explorer and nobleman
had led an expedition into what is now Oklahoma in 1718-19. His original
objective was to establish a trading post near the present city of [Texarkana,
Arkansas](/wiki/Texarkana,_Arkansas "Texarkana, Arkansas"), but he then
extended his trip overland as far north as the Arkansas River (which he
designated as the _Alcansas_). The explorer wrote he and 9 other men,
including three Caddo guides and 22 horses loaded with trade goods had come to
a native settlement overlooking the river, where there were about 6,000
natives, who gave the strangers a warm welcome. La Harpe's party were honored
with the [calumet](/wiki/Ceremonial_pipe "Ceremonial pipe") ceremony and spent
ten days at this location. In 1988, evidence of a native village was
discovered along the Arkansas River 13 miles (21 km) south of present-day
Tulsa, Oklahoma. By then, the site was known as the [Lasley Vore
Site](/wiki/Lasley_Vore_Site "Lasley Vore Site").[12] [a]

French traders and trappers who had opened up trade with Indian tribes in
Canada and the areas around the Great Lakes began exploring the Mississippi
and some of its northern tributaries. They soon learned that the birch-bark
canoes, which had served them so well on the northern waterways, were too
light for use on the southern rivers, such as the Arkansas. They turned to
making and using dugout canoes, which they called _pirogues_ , made by
hollowing out the trunks of [cottonwood](/wiki/Populus_deltoides "Populus
deltoides") trees. [b] Cottonwoods are plentiful along the streams of the
southwest and grow to large sizes. The wood is soft and easily worked with the
crude tools carried by both the French and Indians. The pirogues The pirogues
were sturdier and could be more for navigating the sandbars and snags of the
Southern waterways.[13]

In 1819, the [Adams-Onís Treaty](/wiki/Adams-On%C3%ADs_Treaty "Adams-Onís
Treaty") set the Arkansas as part of the frontier between the United States
and Spanish [Mexico](/wiki/Mexico "Mexico"). This continued until the United
States annexed [Texas](/wiki/Texas "Texas") after the [Mexican-American
War](/wiki/Mexican-American_War "Mexican-American War"), in 1846. The treaty
was made shortly after "Old Settler" [Cherokees](/wiki/Cherokee_nation
"Cherokee nation") moved to near what became known as [Webbers
Falls](/wiki/Webbers_Falls,_Oklahoma "Webbers Falls, Oklahoma") on the
Arkansas River. That area, then part of [Arkansas
Territory](/wiki/Arkansas_Territory "Arkansas Territory") would become [Indian
Territory](/wiki/Indian_Territory "Indian Territory") and later
[Oklahoma](/wiki/Oklahoma "Oklahoma"), was traditional territory of the
[Osage](/wiki/Osage_nation "Osage nation"), leading to conflict and a treaty
in 1828 but still unresolved by the time thousands of additional Cherokee
refugees moved to the area during the [Trail of Tears](/wiki/Trail_of_Tears
"Trail of Tears").[14][15]

By the time Fort Smith was established in 1817, larger capacity watercraft
became available to transport goods up and down the Arkansas. These included
flatboats (_bateaus_) and [keelboats](/wiki/Keelboats "Keelboats"). Along with
the pirogues, they transported piles of deer, bear, otter, beaver and buffalo
skins up and down the river. Agricultural products such as corn, rice, dried
peaches, beans, peanuts, snake root, sarsaparilla, ginseng had grown in
economic importance.[13]

On March 31, 1820, the _Comet_ became the first steamboat to successfully
navigate part of the Arkansas River, reaching a place called [Arkansas
Post](/wiki/Arkansas_Post "Arkansas Post"),{{efn|Arkansas Post is said to have
been the first European settlement in the Mississippi Valley,[13] about 60
miles (97 km) above the confluence of the Arkansas and the Mississippi
Rivers.[16] In mid-April, 1822, the _Robert Thompson_ , towing a keelboat, was
the first steamboat to navigate the Arkansas as far as Fort Smith. For five
years, Fort Smith was known as the head of navigation for steamboats on the
river. It lost the title to Fort Gibson in April, 1832, when three steamboats,
_Velocipede_ , _Scioto_ and _Catawba_ , all arrived at Fort Gibson later that
month.[13]{{efn|Fort Gibson had been built in 1824 on the bank of the
Verdigris River in what had been called the "Three Forks" area of [Indian
Territory](/wiki/Indian_Territory "Indian Territory").

Later, the [Santa Fe Trail](/wiki/Santa_Fe_Trail "Santa Fe Trail") followed
the Arkansas through much of Kansas, picking it up near [Great
Bend](/wiki/Great_Bend,_Kansas "Great Bend, Kansas") and continuing through to
[La Junta, Colorado](/wiki/La_Junta,_Colorado "La Junta, Colorado"), unless
users elected to take the challenging [Cimarron Cutoff](/wiki/Cimarron_Cutoff
"Cimarron Cutoff") in [Cimarron, Kansas](/wiki/Cimarron,_Kansas "Cimarron,
Kansas").[17]

### American Civil
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Arkansas_River&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: American Civil War")]

Main article: [Ambush of the steamboat J. R.
Williams](/wiki/Ambush_of_the_steamboat_J._R._Williams "Ambush of the
steamboat J. R. Williams")

During the American Civil War, each side tried to prevent the other from using
the Arkansas and its tributaries as a route for moving reinforcements.
Initially, the Union Army abandoned its forts in the Indian Territory,
including Fort Gibson and Fort Smith, in order to maximize its strength for
campaigns elsewhere, while the Confederate Army sent troops from Texas to
support its Native American allies. Union Troops returned later in the war,
after defeating the Confederates at the [Battle of Pea
Ridge](/wiki/Battle_of_Pea_Ridge "Battle of Pea Ridge") and the [Battle of
Fort Smith](/wiki/Battle_of_Fort_Smith "Battle of Fort Smith"), and began
recovering the position it had previously abandoned, most notably Fort Gibson,
reopening the Arkansas River as a supply route. In September 1864, a body of
Confederate irregulars led by General Stand Watie successfully ambushed a
Union supply ship bound for Fort Gibson. The vessel was destroyed, and a part
of its cargo was looted by the Confederates.

### Post Civil
War[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Arkansas_River&action=edit&section=7 "Edit
section: Post Civil War")]

In the 1880s, [Charles "Buffalo" Jones](/wiki/Charles_%22Buffalo%22_Jones
"Charles "Buffalo" Jones"), one of the cofounders of [Garden City,
Kansas](/wiki/Garden_City,_Kansas "Garden City, Kansas"), organized four
irrigation companies to take water one hundred miles from the Arkansas River
to cultivate 75,000 acres (300 km2) of land.[18] By 1890, water from the
Arkansas was being used to irrigate more than 20×103 acres (8.1×103 ha) of
farmland in Kansas. By 1910, irrigation projects in Colorado had caused the
river to stop flowing in July and August.[19]

Flooding in 1927 severely damaged or destroyed nearly every levee downstream
of Fort Smith, and led to the development of the Arkansas River Flood Control
Association.[19] It also led to the Federal Government assigning
responsibility of flood control and navigation on the Arkansas to the U.S.
Army Corps of Engineers (USACOE).

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7b/Fly_Fishermen_on_the_Arkansas_River_Near_Salida_Colorado.jpg/220px-

## Angling[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Arkansas_River&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Angling")]

The headwaters of the Arkansas River in central [Colorado](/wiki/Colorado
"Colorado") have been known for exceptional trout fishing, particularly [fly
fishing](/wiki/Fly_fishing "Fly fishing"), since the 19th century, when
[greenback cutthroat trout](/wiki/Greenback_cutthroat_trout "Greenback
cutthroat trout") dominated the river.[20] Today, [brown
trout](/wiki/Brown_trout "Brown trout") dominate the river, which also
contains [rainbow trout](/wiki/Rainbow_trout "Rainbow trout"). _[Trout
Unlimited](/wiki/Trout_Unlimited "Trout Unlimited")_ considers the Arkansas
one of the top 100 trout streams in America,[21] a reputation the river has
had since the 1950s.[22] From Leadville to Pueblo, the Arkansas River is
serviced by numerous fly shops and guides operating in Buena Vista, Salida,
Cañon City and Pueblo. The Colorado Division of Wildlife provides regular
online fishing reports for the river.[23][24]

A [fish kill](/wiki/Fish_kill "Fish kill") occurred on December 29, 2010, in
which an estimated 100,000 [freshwater drum](/wiki/Freshwater_drum "Freshwater
drum") lined the Arkansas River [bank](/wiki/River_bank "River bank").[25][26]
An investigation, conducted by the Arkansas Game and Fish Commission, found
the dead fish "... cover 17 miles of river from the Ozark Lock and Dam
downstream to River Mile 240, directly south of [Hartman,
Arkansas](/wiki/Hartman,_Arkansas "Hartman, Arkansas")."[26] Tests later
indicated the likely cause of the kill was gas bubble trauma caused by opening
the spillways on the Ozark Dam.[27]

qa.question: where is arkansas river located on a map
qa.answer: ['The Arkansas River flows through Colorado, Kansas, Oklahoma, and Arkansas, and its watershed also drains parts of Texas, New Mexico and Missouri.']
